content.description: Left route (facing the wall).  Start by pulling over a tricky bulge next to first bolt.  Continue face climb to top.
content.protection: 5 Bolts. Two bolt chain anchors on top.

content.description: Well protected face climbing on highly featured rock
content.location: Far left end of the wall below the cliff top Saguaro

content.description: Follow the bolt line up a sustained climb.  Watch for loose rocks.
content.protection: 6 Bolts. Two bolt anchor at top.

climbs.name: Nuclear Arsenal
climbs.fa: Kevin Wagner, Benoit Blanc, Sam Head

content.description: Climb the featured face in between the two bolted routes. One or two pieces are nuclear-style bomber and that’s all you’ll need, but many placements are absolute junk. The climbing is pleasant. Be careful.
content.location: In between Angel Eyes and Sarsaparilla.

content.description: This is a fun route and climbs some of the better quality rock on the wall. Start by climbing the ramp to clip the first bolt. A short crux section leads to easier climbing.
content.protection: Four bolts plus two bolt anchor and rap rings.
content.location: Left of Sonoran Moonfire, LMBH climbs up to the obvious roof at the top of the cliff.

content.description: Somewhat more pleasant variation to Black Tail on easier ground to the right.
content.protection: small to medium-sized nuts and cams
content.location: Right of Black Tail, finishing on the same anchor.

content.description: Climb past one bolt and suspect rock into a crack
content.protection: One bolt, medium to large gear, anchor chains
content.location: Starts a few feet right of one legged barstool

content.description: Decently fun and well-protected climbing up the face and crack splitting the main wall.
content.protection: single rack to BD#3, two bolt anchor
content.location: The obvious splitter in the middle of the wall, left of a larger crack beginning with an overhang/layback.

content.description: Short and slightly overhung with mostly positive holds and tightly-spaced bolts. Powerful climbing through the middle makes this an enjoyable climb for those on the tall side. Those on the short side may find things more challenging. The most difficult route at the wall at the time of bolting. Head to Westbound at the San Augustin Mercado for the namesake drink, of which you may spot the namesake bird nestled in the cholla.The anchors are currently lacking chains (August 2021). Until these are upgraded, lower/TR through quickdraws on the two bolt anchor and have the last climber go the extra 10 feet to the top to lower through the chains of Corner Pocket.
content.protection: four bolts plus two bolt anchor
content.location: Right of Corner Pocket, at the start of the overhung section

content.description: This route has surely been climbed before as a top rope, but is far enough from the other bolted lines and climbs such fun features that we thought it would be a good addition to the sport climbing options at this increasingly popular crag. Start on the large block-ladder to the right of the ramp. Big moves on big holds near the third bolt may feel more difficult for shorter climbers. Tightly-spaced bolts and good clipping stances make this a great route for a beginning leader.See Aaron Huey's Ten Sleep guidebook for the naming inspiration.
content.protection: Six bolts plus two bolt anchor
content.location: Located in between the large right-leaning ramp (Sonoran Moonfire) and the vertical crack (Corner Pocket). See photos.

content.description:
Short bouldery route with a low crux.  From the developer, T.m.:"The variation just around to the right that leads into the same crack system is called green(tail)....these have been lead on trad gear.

 When we put these up a black tailed rattler was hanging out at the base hunting mice. It was rad. Green or northern green is another name for these snakes hence the names of the routes"
content.protection: Gear. Anchor bolts with rap rings
content.location: Far left end of the wall

content.description: The anchor to the right of Cactus Wren enables a clean and hard TR on the thin face to the right. This has been cleaned up but was not equipped for lead climbing before the bolting restrictions went into effect. It was previously listed as an open project and now remains as a route that can be only be top roped.
content.protection: 2-bolt anchor on the face. Another anchor (from the original bout of development) exists further back and enables setting a top-rope.
content.location: Right-most anchor at the wall, just right of the current right-most line of bolts (Cactus Wren).

climbs.name: Angel Eyes
climbs.fa: Kevin Wagner, Allie Burnett, Alex Orkwis

content.protection: 3-4 bolts. 2 different sets of anchors to choose from.
content.location: As of 12/29/20, this is the farthest left bolted route on the wall (left of Sasparilla). It ends up at the same anchors as Sasparilla, but uses a different line of bolts to get there.

content.description: A short 5 minute walk from the entrance to Sanctuary Cove, this 45 foot wall presents several moderate and well protected face climbs in a beautiful Sonoran desert setting. The rock is somewhat crumbly (characteristic for the Tucson Mountains) but the climbs are reasonably safe. The original climbs (including Sonoran Moonfire and One Legged Barstool) were done in 2015. Additional development in 2019-2021 has cleaned up the area significantly and added more climbing options. There is an easy walk off from the top to descend or set up a top rope from.Near-roadside climbing, morning and afternoon shade (though not mild-day), and majority of moderates have made the Saloon grow in popularity. Please be respectful, keep group sizes small, and use the consolidated trail that accessed the middle of the cliff (not creating side trails from the edges).Routes Face: Southwest · WestSun Starts: ~10amSun Ends: ~3pm (later in Summer)WARNING (posted 5/31/21):  I have been informed there are an unusually large amount of bees around the base and top of the cliff that present a real hazard.  Recall that a Tucson climber died on rappel in 2013 from a bee attack, so please take this seriously.  In addition to that plus the summer heat, this crag should be avoided wholesale till it is determined safe.Update (via KW, from June-July 2021): the bees are still present, but are not an obvious danger. One member of our party was stung once while walking to the top, but the bees made no attempt to swarm. They didn’t mind our continued presence and loud noise level. Caution is still warranted, but we’ve still been enjoying the area without issue.
